description:
Turkey has said it won’t reopen schools until September, but distance learning programs will continue until June 19 in line with the government’s gradual plan to reopen the country amid the continued COVID-19 pandemic. 

“The 2019-2020 education year for the schools under the Education Ministry has been terminated. The new school year will begin in September,” President Recep Tayyip Erdoğan said in his address after a weekly cabinet meeting late May 18. 

As part of measures to curb the spread of the novel coronavirus, Turkey shut down the primary, secondary and high schools on March 16 and launched a distance learning program on March 23 for around 18 million students.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Preschool or childcare facilities (generally for children ages 5 and below)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: As of June 9, 2020, the President of Turkey announces a curfew regime for those over the age of 65 or persons whose immune system is compromised due to chronic pulmonary diseases, asthma, COPD, cardiovascular, kidney, hypertension, and liver disease. They can only go outside from 10 am to 8 pm. As of August 14, 2020, the Health Minister of Turkey announces the end of nationwide curfew regimes for those over the age of 65 or persons whose immune system is compromised due to chronic diseases. From August 14, 2020, onward, Provincial Public Hygiene Boards will decide specific curfew regimes if necessary. UPDATE: As of August 14, 2020, the Health Minister of Turkey announces that nationwide curfew regimes for those over the age of 65 or persons whose immune system is compromised due to chronic diseases end. From August 14, 2020, onward, Provincial Public Hygiene Boards will decide specific curfew regimes if necessary.

description:
Turkish Airlines announced on Friday that it would temporarily halt flights to and from four destinations in China due to the coronavirus outbreak.

"In order to evaluate the situation and recent developments regarding the coronavirus with national and international authorities, we are suspending our flights to the cities of Beijing, Guangzhou, Shanghai and Xian until Feb. 9," Yahya Üstün, the airlines’ senior vice president for media relations

description:
National flag carrier Turkish Airlines (THY) has extended the cancellation of its international flights due to the coronavirus outbreak, the company said Tuesday.

The company will not fly on international routes until May 20, 2020 "in accordance with the decisions taken by the authorities of Turkey and to protect the public health from novel coronavirus pandemic."

description: In response to the Omicron COVID-19 variant, Turkey will be closing its borders to those who have been in South Africa, Mozambique, Botswana, Namibia, and Zimbabwe. description: The Ministry of Health began opening "Covid-19 Tracking Centers" on 16 December 2020 for the control and follow-up of the health status of COVID-19 patients. Two centers in Ankara and Eskisehir provinces started a pilot project that the MoH aims to eventually spread throughout the country in 30 health districts across Turkey’s 24 provinces.

description:
The Turkish Red Crescent collected 3,970 immune plasmas donated across the country amid the novel coronavirus outbreak, according to the group's top official.

Kerem Kınık, head of the aid agency, told Anadolu Agency that the immune plasma therapy is considered as a supportive treatment for COVID-19, adding that the agency has taken steps along with the Health Ministry on this
issue.

The first plasma, Kınık said, was donated on April 7, and some 3,500 Red Crescent employees worked in two shifts during this period in plasma apheresis centers in 14 cities to receive blood and plasma donations.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)
type_sub_cat: Other Health Materials
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: Ministry/Department of Health,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
Turkey has sent medical aid to 80 countries to fight the novel coronavirus, the country’s vice president said Thursday (May 14).   

“We have had the opportunity to help 80 countries that have asked us for help so far,” Fuat Oktay said.

The main demand from these countries was face masks, gloves and respirators, Oktay said.  

He said two-thirds of the countries in the world, or close to 70%, had requested assistance from Turkey.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Masks
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government

description:
Ramping up its testing capabilities since confirming its first COVID-19 case on March 10, Turkey has carried out more than a million coronavirus tests so far.

According to Health Minister Fahrettin Koca on Thursday (April 30), Turkey carried out 42,004 tests in the last 24 hours, bringing the total number of tests to 1,033,617. The figure puts Turkey seventh in the world in terms of the total number of COVID-19 tests carried out.
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)

description:
Turkey on March 27 introduced more stringent measures for the COVID-19 pandemic in 30 big cities, bans intercity travels.
According to the new measures the president announced, traveling between cities will now be possible with the permission of local governors.

 UPDATE: Travel restrictions have been lifted in nine Turkish provinces as the government continues to ease measures it imposed to control the spread of the coronavirus.

The Interior Ministry lifted the ban on travel in and out of Adana, Denizli, Diyarbakır, Kahramanmaraş, Mardin, Ordu, Şanlıurfa, Tekirdağ and Trabzon provinces on Tuesday morning.

The restrictions will continue for another week in the 15 remaining provinces where the ban was imposed in March: Ankara, Balıkesir, Bursa, Eskişehir, Gaziantep, Istanbul, Izmir, Kayseri, Kocaeli, Konya, Manisa, Sakarya, Samsun, Van and Zonguldak.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Municipal Government,Police

update_level_var: [target_direction] of policy strengthening ; [compliance]  of policy strengthening ; timing of policy strengthening
description:
Turkey on March 27 introduced more stringent measures for the COVID-19 pandemic in 30 big cities, bans intercity travels.
According to the new measures the president announced, traveling between cities will now be possible with the permission of local governors.

 UPDATE: Turkey officially extended a travel ban in 15 major cities for 15 more days due to the pandemic, according to Interior Ministry on May 19. 

In a statement, the ministry said the travel ban will continue between May 20 and June 3 and those who do not comply with the travel restrictions will be imposed administrative fines.

The ministry added that air, land, and sea travel to and from these provinces will be restricted.

The cities with the travel ban include Istanbul, Ankara, İzmir, Balıkesir, Bursa, Eskisehir, Gaziantep, Kayseri, Kocaeli, Konya, Manisa, Sakarya, Samsun, Van, and Zonguldak.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Municipal Government,Police

update_level_var: [target_direction] of policy strengthening ; [compliance]  of policy strengthening ; timing of policy strengthening
description:
Turkey on March 27 introduced more stringent measures for the COVID-19 pandemic in 30 big cities, bans intercity travels.
According to the new measures the president announced, traveling between cities will now be possible with the permission of local governors.

 UPDATE: Tickets for the high-speed train were offered for sale on May 25 ahead of the resumption of services later this week, while major intercity bus companies have announced the recommencement of their services in early June.

Turkey has been gradually easing the measures initially introduced to arrest the spread of the coronavirus, and as part of these efforts the railway authority plans to relaunch the high-speed train services between Ankara and Istanbul, the western province of Eskişehir and the Central Anatolian province of Konya as of May 28.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Municipal Government,Police

description: On April 3, 2020, the Ministry of Health in Turkey, announced a lockdown, effective midnight on April 4, for those who are over the age of 65 or persons whose immune system is compromised due to chronic pulmonary diseases, asthma, COPD, cardiovascular disease, kidney disease, hypertension, liver disease, and people twenty and younger. As of May 4, 2020, the Turkish government announced that up to 4 hours going out between 11.00 to 15.00 would be allowed. The government will halt restrictions between May 10, 2020, and May 15, 2020. Citizens over the age of 65 can go out on May 10, 2020. Citizens aged between 0-14 can go out on May 13, and citizens aged between 15-20 can go out on May 15. They should be within walking distance. UPDATE: The original policy banned going out. It now allows up to 4 hours going out on certain days.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description:
Turkey has decided to impose a 4-day nationwide lockdown over the Eid al-Fitr holiday between May 23-26 as part of measures taken against the coronavirus pandemic, President Recep Tayyip Erdoğan announced Monday (May 17) following a weekly cabinet meeting.

Ankara has imposed lockdowns across major cities over the past five weekends, as well as on national holidays, in order to slow the spread of the new coronavirus.

description:
The Turkish government is planning to ban layoffs for three months in a bid to protect those lacking job security and to ease damages to the economy due to the coronavirus outbreak, according to a draft legislation.
The bill would apply to anyone who had been laid off or put on unpaid leave as of March 15 and is not eligible for unemployment benefits. They would be paid daily 39.24 liras ($5.80) by the government.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_text: Turkey to ban layoffs for three months to ease COVID-19 impact
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government

description: Persons who die from coronavirus-related complications are buried in coffins in Istanbul and the communal funeral prayers before the burial are eliminated, an official from the provincial cemeteries directorate said. While morticians now wear personal protective equipment, burial spots aren’t lined with lime.In Islam, the dead are buried with no clothes on, but wrapped in shrouds instead. However, anyone who dies from the coronavirus in Istanbul now gets buried in a coffin.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_text: Persons who die from coronavirus-related complications are buried in coffins in Istanbul and the communal funeral prayers before the burial are eliminated
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
enforcer: Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government

description:
President launches National Solidarity Campaign

Turkey's president on Monday launched a National Solidarity Campaign to aid fight against the novel coronavirus, donating seven of his monthly salaries to the initiative. He underlined that the aim of the campaign would be to provide additional support to low-income people suffering economically due to the measures taken against the spread of the disease.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
type_text: National Solidarity Campaign to aid fight against the novel coronavirus.  the aim of the campaign would be to provide additional support to low-income people suffering economically due to the measures taken against the spread of the disease.
target_geog_level: One or more regional groupings
enforcer: National Government

description:
Turkey has initiated a partial normalization process as the country’s fight against the coronavirus pandemic has proven effective and a decline in the number of new infections and deaths is reflected in the figures. (May 4) Now, an action plan for the tourism sector is set to be implemented to revive the country's virus-hit industry safely and steadily.

The normalization process for the industry will include various measures, from imposing social distancing rules in crowded places to providing face masks to the tourists.

According to the newly announced action plan, a certification system will be implemented for both hotels and transfer vehicles. All details were taken into consideration for the certification program, from the training of the hotel employees to the reorganizing of buffets, restaurants, meeting rooms or pool areas.

Disinfectants will be available at every transfer vehicle, while the seats on each side of the passenger will be left empty.

The hotels will be given a maximum occupancy permit of 60% and the hotel owners will provide masks to tourists without masks. At the entrance of the hotels, visitors' body temperatures will be checked and lines marking social distancing will be used at reception and lobby.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_text: Turkey reveals normalization plan for tourism sector amid pandemic
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government

description:
The total number of recoveries from coronavirus in Turkey rose to 106,133, the country’s health minister said on Friday (May 15).

The death toll from the pandemic rose to 4,055 as the country reported 48 new fatalities over the past 24 hours, Fahrettin Koca said, citing the Health Ministry data.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health

description:
Turkey's Trade Ministry stepped up to support export-oriented businesses amid the pandemic by organizing the first virtual trade fair on June 1-3, following a trade delegation's online meetings
The emergence of the coronavirus pandemic had initially halted world trade by not only disrupting supply chains and export-import channels but also causing the cancellation or postponement of various small- or large-scale global trade fairs. Countries now looking to find new solutions to resume trade are considering their options. Meanwhile, Turkey’s Trade Ministry stepped up to organize trade fairs online, the first one of which is scheduled for June 1-3.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_text: Turkish Trade Ministry organizes virtual global business fairs amid pandemic
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
The first seeds of the Stay at Home Forest campaign, organized by Innovative Center for Entrepreneurship Center (BAUICE) of Bahçeşehir University, will be planted on June 5, 2020.

To support the stay-at-home measures to curb the spread of coronavirus, one seed ball will be thrown by drones at Stay at Home Forest in Ankara for each day people stay home.

The project is being carried out by the Ecording team consisting of young entrepreneurs of BAUICE with the support of the General Directory of Forestry and partner brands.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
target_geog_level: One or more cities within one or more countries
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)

description:
Turkey keeps updating its contingency plan against coronavirus as more cases are reported. Those arriving from Europe are being placed in quarantine.
As the number of confirmed coronavirus cases in Turkey rose to 18 Monday(March 16), the country imposed new measures in the fight against the deadly outbreak. Authorities announced that student dormitories in Istanbul were being evacuated to accommodate people returning from coronavirus-hit European countries. Travelers will be quarantined there for 14 days. UPDATE: All other international arrivals (European) must present a negative PCR test taken within 72 hours of departure, or an antigen test taken within 48 hours of departure. You can skip these with either proof of a Covid-19 infection in the past six months or of vaccination at least 14 days before arrival.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Other Quarantine
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health

description:
Some 50 barbers have been put under quarantine in the Tavşanlı district of the western province of Kütahya after a doctor, who was part of the inspection team, tested positive for COVID-19.

Turkey recently allowed barber shops and hair salons to reopen across the country as part of its program to relax coronavirus measures but said that teams will carry out regular inspections to see if those shops comply with health regulations.

Around 100 barber shops in Tavşanlı recommenced their service last week in line with new regulations and inspection teams visited those businesses. However, it emerged that a doctor, who was part of the inspection crew, had COVID-19.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Self-Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at home)
target_geog_level: One or more cities within one or more countries
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Passengers who have been in Bangladesh, Brazil, South Africa, India, Nepal and Sri Lanka in the last 14 days must submit a negative PCR test taken within 72 hours prior to entering Turkey and undergo a mandatory 14 day quarantine after June 28, 2021

description: As of November 20, 2020, the Turkish Grand National Assembly in Ankara requires a HES code, an SMS, or a QR code, that reveals Covid-19 patients or contacted people. Those people who cannot provide a HES code cannot enter the TGNA premises.

description: Turkey's parliament on Tuesday (April 14) passed a law to allow tens of thousands of prisoners to be released to curb the spread of the coronavirus in the country's overcrowded prisons, but the exclusion of those jailed on "terrorism" charges in the crackdown following the 2016 coup drew criticism.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
type_sub_cat: Prison population reduced (e.g. early release of prisoners)
enforcer: National Government

description:
Turkey’s Interior Ministry issued a circular on April 22 on measures that will be taken against the novel coronavirus during the Islamic fasting month of Ramadan.
According to the circular, crowded events and tents where people would usually convene for iftar or to break their fast will not be allowed. The ministry said all necessary precautions will be taken during iftar and sahur – the meal before starting the fast at dawn - to maintain social distancing outdoors.The selling time of pide, a traditional round and flat bread generally consumed during the fasting month, will be terminated two hours before iftar in order to prevent crowds from gathering at bakeries.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Attendance at religious services restricted (e.g. mosque/church closings)
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
Istanbul’s historical Grand Bazaar, one of the oldest surviving shopping centers in the world, has been completely closed to visitors as part of the measures Turkey has taken in a bid to stop the spread of the coronavirus pandemic.

Until March 23, people could visit the historical venue between 10 a.m. and 4 p.m. only through two entrances.

As of yesterday, all visitors were banned and only business owners and employees are allowed after ID checks.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Cancellation of an annually recurring event
enforcer: National Government,Municipal Government

description:
Istanbul’s historical Grand Bazaar, one of the oldest surviving shopping centers in the world, has been completely closed to visitors as part of the measures Turkey has taken in a bid to stop the spread of the coronavirus pandemic.

Until March 23, people could visit the historical venue between 10 a.m. and 4 p.m. only through two entrances.

As of yesterday, all visitors were banned and only business owners and employees are allowed after ID checks. UPDATE: Istanbul’s iconic Grand Bazaar will re-open for shopping on June 1 after a two-month closure due to the COVID-19 outbreak, Turkey’s state-run Anadolu news agency said.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Cancellation of an annually recurring event
enforcer: National Government,Municipal Government

description:
Turkey announced new measures to contain the spread of coronavirus that go into effect at midnight on Monday (March 16).

According to the Turkish Interior Ministry, these public places will be closed for an unspecified period of time:

Theaters, concert halls, wedding halls, music halls, taverns, cafeterias, game halls, beer halls, cafes, coffee parlors, tea parlors, hookah bars, Internet cafes, gaming cafes, all indoor playgrounds, tea gardens, amusement parks, pools, saunas, gyms, spas, sports complexes and massage parlors UPDATE: As the country has made progress in the fight against the coronavirus, President Recep Tayyip Erdoğan on May 28 unveiled the steps taken toward the “new normal.”

Under the steps for the next phase, excluding places of entertainment, enterprises such as restaurants, patisseries, cafes, tea gardens, swimming pools and hot springs are set to recommence their operations on June 1.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Cancellation of a recreational or commercial event
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government

description: Turkey is taking some of its biggest steps yet to ease its coronavirus restrictions. Flights and car travel resumed between big cities on Monday (June 6). Cafes, restaurants, parks and museums have begun to reopen. And: Istanbul's 15th-century Grand Bazaar is back in business. UPDATE: Istanbul's iconic Grand Bazaar reopens on Monday (June 6) as Turkey eases up
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Cancellation of an annually recurring event
enforcer: National Government,Municipal Government

description:
The Turkish leader on Tuesday (November 3) announced measures to be reintroduced to stem the spread of coronavirus, with several public places to close earlier.

Hairdressers, wedding halls, swimming pools, astroturfs, theaters, cinemas, concert halls, and similar places will close at 10 p.m. (1900GMT), Recep Tayyip Erdogan told a news conference in the capital Ankara following the Cabinet meeting at the presidential complex.

The restrictions will also apply to cafes and restaurants, however, they will be allowed to offer food for takeaway after 10 p.m. UPDATE: The Turkish leader on Tuesday (November 3) announced measures to be reintroduced to stem the spread of coronavirus, with several public places to close earlier. Hairdressers, wedding halls, swimming pools, astroturfs, theaters, cinemas, concert halls, and similar places will close at 10 p.m. (1900GMT). The restrictions will also apply to cafes and restaurants, however, they will be allowed to offer food for takeaway after 10 p.m.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Cancellation of a recreational or commercial event
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government

description: Turkey has put a limit on all passengers taking public transport within and between cities. Public transport will from now on only accept passengers up to 50% of the entire carriage capacity of the vehicle. UPDATE: Restrictions on capacity for intracity and intercity public transportation will be lifted on 1 July 2021 as part of an overall normalization period.
